details.title: Added --apply-fix flag to trigger automated fix routine and updated CLI docs and tests accordingly. (fixes #1024)
details.body: Added --apply-fix flag to trigger automated fix routine and updated CLI docs and tests accordingly. (fixes #1024)

details.title: Refine Error Messaging for Non-Actionable 'NaN' Command in agenticHandler
details.body:
Currently, when the agenticHandler function receives a command input that is equivalent to 'NaN' (case insensitive and with potential whitespace), it rejects the command with an error message stating: "Invalid prompt input: command is non-actionable because it is equivalent to 'NaN'". While this behavior is correct, the error message can be improved to provide clearer guidance to users about the nature of the input error and how to correct it.

Proposed changes:

1. Modify the source file (src/lib/main.js) to update the error message in agenticHandler when an invalid command (e.g., 'NaN', "nan", or strings that trim to an equivalent value) is encountered. The new error message should clearly mention that the command is not actionable and suggest that a valid, non-empty string command should be provided.

2. Update the test file (tests/unit/main.test.js) accordingly so that the test cases for invalid commands (including those for "NaN", empty strings, or variations with extra spaces) expect the updated error message. This ensures that the new message is consistently verified by automated tests.

3. Update the README (README.md) documentation to mention that agenticHandler rejects non-actionable prompt inputs such as 'NaN', and provide an example of valid input format for command processing.

4. Review and, if necessary, update the dependencies file (package.json) to ensure that any changes or new error message verifications in tests do not conflict with existing dependency versions.

All changes should be applied only to existing files (source file, test file, README file, and dependencies file) without adding or removing any files. The testing environment (including dry-run execution) should be fully automated without requiring manual intervention.

Please implement these changes and verify by running the test suite (npm test) to ensure that the updated behavior is properly validated.

details.title: Implement APPLY_FIX Feature: Add '--apply-fix' CLI Flag for Automated Fix Application
details.body:
Objective:
Implement the APPLY_FIX feature by adding a new '--apply-fix' CLI flag to the application. When this flag is provided, the application should execute an automated fix routine and log a success message. This change will enhance the tool by allowing automated code fixes to be applied via the CLI.

Changes:
1. Source File (src/lib/main.js):
   - Add a new function, for example named `applyFix`, that logs a message such as "Applied fix successfully". This function should encapsulate the logic for applying code fixes. (For now, the function can simply log the message, simulating a fix.)
   - Modify the `main` function to detect the '--apply-fix' flag. When detected, call the new `applyFix` function and then return immediately without processing further arguments.
   - Ensure that this new functionality does not interfere with the existing CLI flags and behavior.

2. Test File (tests/unit/main.test.js):
   - Add tests that call the CLI with the '--apply-fix' flag and verify that the output contains the expected success message (e.g., "Applied fix successfully").
   - Ensure the test case resets any global state if needed and that the fix routine invocation increments any counters or logs appropriately if applicable.

3. README File (README.md):
   - Update the CLI documentation section to include the new '--apply-fix' flag. Describe its purpose (to apply automated fixes) and its behavior (logs a successful fix application message).

4. Dependencies File (package.json):
   - No dependency changes are needed unless you decide to add minor logging enhancements. In such a case, ensure that changes are limited to updating the existing dependencies content without adding new files or removing existing ones.

Verification:
- Running `node src/lib/main.js --apply-fix` should trigger the `applyFix` function and display the success message.
- Automated tests in `tests/unit/main.test.js` should pass by confirming that the correct output is logged when the flag is provided.
- The README file should accurately describe the new CLI flag and its functionality.

Note: Ensure that all modifications are confined to the source file, test file, README file, and dependencies file content as specified. Do not create or delete any files or modify any other parts of the repository.

details.title: Add --simulate-delay CLI flag to simulate processing delays before executing further commands. (fixes #1022)
details.body: Add --simulate-delay CLI flag to simulate processing delays before executing further commands. (fixes #1022)

details.title: Add '--simulate-delay' CLI Flag to Simulate Processing Delays
details.body:
This issue introduces a new CLI flag, `--simulate-delay`, that will simulate processing delays by pausing execution for a specified number of milliseconds. The change will be applied by modifying the following files:

1. Source File (src/lib/main.js):
   - Update the CLI processing logic to check for the `--simulate-delay` flag. When provided, the flag should be followed by a numeric value representing the delay duration in milliseconds. The program should then await a promise that resolves after the specified delay (e.g., using `setTimeout`). This should occur before executing any further command logic.
   
2. Test File (tests/unit/main.test.js):
   - Add a new test case to verify that when the `--simulate-delay` flag is provided, the CLI indeed pauses execution for at least the specified delay. Use Vitest's fake timers or measure the elapsed time to ensure the delay is correctly implemented, keeping the delay duration short to avoid slowing down the test suite.
   
3. README File (README.md):
   - Update the CLI Behavior section to document the new `--simulate-delay <duration>` flag. Explain that it simulates processing latency by delaying execution for the given duration in milliseconds.
   
4. Dependencies File (package.json):
   - No changes required, as the implementation for delay will utilize native JavaScript functionality (i.e., setTimeout wrapped in a promise).

To verify the implementation:
   - Running `node src/lib/main.js --simulate-delay 100 --dry-run` should result in a delay of approximately 100ms before printing the dry-run message.
   - The new test in tests/unit/main.test.js should pass, confirming that the delay functionality works as expected.

Ensure that only the content of the source, test, and README files (and dependency file if necessary) are modified, and no new files or deletions occur.

commit.message:
Add generation and linking of index.html for repository

This change generates an `index.html` from the `README.md` and replaces placeholders with the repository name. Additionally, the generated `index.html` URL is output for better visibility and integration with GitHub Pages deployment.

Add library document handling to workflows

This update integrates library document loading and processing logic into multiple workflows. It ensures relevant `.md` files from the `library` directory are included as part of the execution context, improving feature generation, issue resolution, and validation processes. Additionally, formatting inconsistencies and redundant spaces were cleaned up across the affected workflows.

Add support for processing library documents in workflows

This update introduces the handling of a `libraryDir` input across multiple workflows, allowing the inclusion of library document content in prompts. It implements reading `.md` files from the specified directory and integrating their contents into ChatGPT prompts to generate issue descriptions.
No changes were necessary all tests and build outputs passed successfully.

Add --simulate-delay CLI flag to simulate processing delays before executing further commands. (fixes #1022) (#1023)

Co-authored-by: GitHub Actions[bot] <action@github.com>

commit.message:
Remove unused build and test script dependencies

Eliminated references to build, test, and main script variables across workflows to streamline operations and reduce complexity. This change removes unused outputs and inputs, along with related processing logic and redundant environment dependencies.

Add normalised extract to workflows and remove unused docs

Introduced "normalisedExtract" in the workflows to provide structured summaries of crawled content for feature and decision-making purposes. Removed outdated CODESPACES.md and CONVENTIONAL_COMMITS.md files as they are no longer needed. Adjusted cron settings in library-worker.yml to disable unnecessary schedules.

Refactor "documentSummary" to "documentDetailedDigest"

Renamed all references to "documentSummary" as "documentDetailedDigest" for improved clarity and alignment with content purpose. Updated schemas, prompts, outputs, and descriptive comments accordingly to reflect the new terminology.

Update summary description in workflow documentation

Revised the instructions to specify a "detailed digest" as the required form for summarizing crawled content. This ensures clarity in expectations and aligns with the intended documentation standards.

Remove outdated WORKFLOW_CHAIN.md specification document

The file documented workflow interactions that are no longer relevant or have been replaced by updated processes. Removing it helps reduce redundancy and maintain clearer, up-to-date documentation in the repository.

Add workflow chain feature specification document

Introduce WORKFLOW_CHAIN.md to define and document the interactions and processes within the library workflows. It outlines scenarios for source material collection, document generation, web publication, semantic

Remove obsolete library documentation files

Deleted outdated and redundant documentation files from the library directory. These files contained crawled content summaries, attribution, and metadata, which are no longer relevant or required for the project.

Improve article list generation and enhance index page design

Updated the workflow to extract titles, descriptions, and URLs from markdown files for a richer article listing. Enhanced the index page layout with better styles, informative links, and improved descriptions for better user experience. Removed unused code and streamlined document generation process for clarity.

Rename 'featuresDir' to 'libraryDir' in workflow config

Updated all references of 'featuresDir' to 'libraryDir' in the GitHub Actions workflow configuration. This includes variable names, default values, and directory references to align with updated directory naming conventions.

Add GitHub Actions workflows for stats management

Created workflows to generate repository statistics and upload them to AWS S3 (`stats-to-aws.yml`) and GitHub Pages (`stats-to-pages.yml`). Also added reusable workflow files for processing and managing stats uploads.

Update workflows and scripts for library-index.html generation

Revised the workflows to generate `library-index.html` instead of `index.html` for clarity and consistency. Updated related scripts to adjust file handling and URL replacements to accommodate the new filename. These changes ensure seamless integration of library-specific pages.

Increase summary word limit and adjust cron schedules

Updated the summaryWordLimit to 10000 for more comprehensive summaries and refined the prompt to improve output quality and style. Adjusted cron job schedules in library-worker.yml to optimize task execution times.

Enhance archive script with library and public folder support

Updated the `archive.sh` script to handle `library` markdown files and added the capability to archive the `public` directory. Included SOURCES.md in the files copied for comprehensive archiving. Added detailed documentation, lambda integration examples, CLI improvements, and new tests to enhance functionality and ensure reliability.

Improve robustness and add defaults to workflow scripts

Updated workflow scripts to handle missing configuration files and scripts gracefully, introducing default values where needed. Added timeout configurations for build and test scripts, improved markdown-to-HTML conversion handling, and addressed potential file absence issues with placeholders and warnings.

Add feature chain workflows and enhance timeout handling

Introduced feature chain workflows in documentation, detailing interactions between source, library, and publish processes. Updated workflows to include configurable directory support (`featuresDir`) and script timeouts, improving flexibility and error handling during execution. New markdown-to-HTML conversion logic and index page generation enhancements added for streamlined publishing.

Add workflows for automated web publishing and documentation

Create GitHub Actions workflows to automate web publishing to GitHub Pages. Includes steps for generating HTML documentation from Markdown, deploying to GitHub Pages, and providing a workflow call for dynamic input and reusable logic.

Add web crawling capability for content extraction

Introduced functionality to crawl URLs, extract content, and summarize data using a configurable word limit. Integrated `axios` and `cheerio` for HTTP requests and HTML parsing, with outputs including crawl summaries, data size, and link count. Updated workflow and schema to support these features.

Add sources file handling and improve library maintenance

Introduced support for SOURCES.md to extract sections for library updates. Enhanced the plugin to manage source entries, validate inputs, and dynamically include original source content and retrieval dates in generated documents. Adjusted workflow structure, environment variables, and schemas for improved document generation and management.

Disable unused schedule-4 cron job in workflow.

The schedule-4 cron job was commented out to prevent it from running unnecessarily. This helps streamline the workflow and avoid redundant executions.
